title: Tools for Survey-Based Prediction in ABCD
text: Here is a link to the Github Repository containing abcd-itembuild, an R project that filters the ABCD 6.0 dataset down to items eligible for survey-based prediction models, makes necessary recodes to items, and outputs metadata-ABCD-items.csv.

title: Tools for Survey-Based Prediction in ABCD
text: Here is a link to the Github Repository containing abcd-itembuild, an R project that filters the ABCD 6.0 dataset down to items eligible for survey-based prediction models, makes necessary recodes to items, and outputs metadata-ABCD-items.csv.

Item Metadata Download
Here is the link to the csv file (metadata-ABCD-items.csv) for the item metadata.

title: Metadata Explorer
text: On youth substance use data: Youth substance use data has yet to be evaluated as potential items for TSP-ABCD. We expect to finish evaluating youth substance use data and update this page by end of January 2026.

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Frequently Asked Questions
If you have a question that is not currently addressed here, please reach out to <wpelham at ucsd dot edu>.

Will the code in abcd-itembuild work if I don’t have the ABCD Study data?
No, you must attain access to the ABCD 6.0 release (only available directly from the NIH) for the code to work. It is highly specific to the ABCD dataset.


Is the code available in another programming language aside from R?
No, currently the only available code for this project is in R.


How did you create the metadata?
Pelham Lab research assistants evaluated the entirety of the metadata from the ABCD 6.0 release under the supervision of Dr. William Pelham III. Variables were first evaluated on the basis of viability as a question on a survey. If a variable could be a survey question, it was then evaluated on the following:
a) administration of the variable in the core study (such that all eligible ABCD participants could have completed the variable) ,
b) administration of the variable happening outside of the eligibility screener,
c) if gating is present, the variable’s ability to be combined with the gating question(s) to produce a straightforward single question with a single set of responses with a monotonic relationship with the outcomes , and
d) any other reason that would make presenting the variable on a predictive screening battery difficult.
Columns were also created to facilitate recoding potential items and also to sort/categorize the items.
More information on how we created the bespoke metadata can be found here.


How did you decide which variables to recode, and how to recode them?
Variables were recoded for the following reasons:

The same variable was split into two or more separate variables: usually a baseline variable and a longitudinal variable. For example, the question “Has she/he [your child] ever been to a doctor for allergies” is asked at baseline, responses for which are stored in the variable ph_p_mhx_002. Following baseline, the question is rephrased as “Since we last saw you, has your child been to a doctor for allergies”, responses for which are stored in ph_p_mhx_002__l. Upon evaluating that there is no meaningful change in the contents of the question itself, these variables were combined into the baseline variable, after which we deleted the longitudinal variable.
The variable itself did not have responses that were monotonic (linear). For example, the question
What best describes your child’s current school setting?
can only elicit responses that are not linear (e.g., “public school”, “private school”, “home school”, etc.). To be able to use the content of these variables in our prediction models, we recoded each response to these nonlinear variables as binary (0/1) items (e.g., child_in_reg_public_school, child_in_reg_private_school, child_in_online_school, etc.).
The variable was gated by another variable, such that only a subsection of the full ABCD participant pool responded to it AND answers from the gating question(s) could be imputed as responses to the gated variable. For example, the question “About how many hours per week does your child spend listening to music for pleasure?” is only presented to parents who endorse that their child listens to music for pleasure. We know, however, that parents who do not endorse that their child listens to music, if presented with the question, “About how many hours per week does your child spend listening to music for pleasure?” would have responded with “0 hours.” As such, we impute 0s for hours of music listening per week for people who responded “no” to the gating question.
The variable was in units that could not be adequately represented in a linear model (e.g., hours and minutes) without recoding (e.g., 3:30 pm –> 15.5)



Where are the items measuring youth substance use?
TSP-ABCD was initially conceptualized as a predictive tool for the outcome of high-risk, early substance use. As such, the lab prioritized evaluating whether variables could be considered items when they did not contain youth substance use. We are currently working on evaluating these variables and will update the metadata on this website once we have finished. Here is a spreadsheet containing all potential items flagged for youth substance use.


I think there is a bug in your code or error in your metadata — what should I do?
Please report any bugs or errors to < placeholder at health dot ucsd dot edu >


What is “ALEXSA” and why is it included in the metadata?
Assessment of Liability and EXposure to Substance use and Antisocial behavior for Children (ALEXSA) assessment (Ridenour et al., 2009) is a child report assessment for predictors of early onset substance abuse and for antisocial behavior. The “alexsa_facet” featured in metadata-ABCD-items.csv was created through evaluating whether each item fit into one of the 34 subscales.


How do I acknowledge / cite this tool?
TBD


Where can I read more about creating and evaluating predictive modeling tools?
Here are some references!
Steyerberg, E. W., & Harrell, F. E. (2016). Prediction models need appropriate internal, internal–external, and external validation. Journal of Clinical Epidemiology, 69, 245–247. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclinepi.2015.04.005
Japkowicz, N., & Shah, M. (2011). Evaluating Learning Algorithms: A Classification Perspective. Cambridge University Press.
Hemingway, H., Croft, P., Perel, P., Hayden, J. A., Abrams, K., Timmis, A., Briggs, A., Udumyan, R., Moons, K. G. M., Steyerberg, E. W., Roberts, I., Schroter, S., Altman, D. G., & Riley, R. D. (2013). Prognosis research strategy (PROGRESS) 1: A framework for researching clinical outcomes. BMJ, 346, e5595. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.e5595 
Riley, R. D., Hayden, J. A., Steyerberg, E. W., Moons, K. G. M., Abrams, K., Kyzas, P. A., Malats, N., Briggs, A., Schroter, S., Altman, D. G., Hemingway, H., & Group,  for the P. (2013). Prognosis research strategy (PROGRESS) 2: Prognostic factor research. PLOS Medicine, 10(2), e1001380. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pmed.1001380 
Steyerberg, E. W., Moons, K. G. M., Windt, D. A. van der, Hayden, J. A., Perel, P., Schroter, S., 
Riley, R. D., Hemingway, H., Altman, D. G., & Group,  for the P. (2013). Prognosis research strategy (PROGRESS) 3: Prognostic model research. PLOS Medicine, 10(2), e1001381. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pmed.1001381
Hingorani, A. D., Windt, D. A. van der, Riley, R. D., Abrams, K., Moons, K. G. M., Steyerberg, E. W., Schroter, S., Sauerbrei, W., Altman, D. G., & Hemingway, H. (2013). Prognosis research strategy (PROGRESS) 4: Stratified medicine research. BMJ, 346, e5793. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.e5793

title: About TRS-ABCD
text:
This is the website for navigating Tools for Risk Scores in the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development Study (TRS-ABCD). Created by the Pelham Lab, TRS-ABCD provides researchers familiar with the ABCD study with practical tools to create predictive survey and / or screening models in the ABCD Study. If you do not already have access to the ABCD Study, you can request access to it through the National Institute of Health (NIH). For more information about the ABCD Study, click here. You will need R to use TRS-ABCD.
To get started:

If you don’t already have it, obtain access to the ABCD 6.0 data (only available directly through the NIH)
Download the code repository This code will take the ABCD Study 6.0 data and create a tidy dataframe with individual survey items ready to plug into a predictive model.

If you do not use R, you can still download our item metadata (metadata-ABCD-items.csv) to work on survey-based projects. The items in the metadata consist of the entirety of variables that could be presented on a survey with little to no context.
***
Development of this website and the associated work was funded by a grant from the National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA), DA058314.
The analysis methodologies, findings, and interpretations expressed in publications using TSP-ABCD are those of the authors and do not constitute an endorsement from the Pelham Lab.

If you do not use R, you can still download our item metadata (metadata-ABCD-items.csv) to work on survey-based projects. The items in the metadata consist of the entirety of variables that could be presented on a survey with little to no context.

title: Introduction
text:
What is this website?
This website describes a set of tools we created for developing prediction models and uncovering risk scores using data from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study release [6.0]
Here are some examples of prediction models you might want to develop:

Predict which children ages 9-10 will develop substance use problems by age 18
Predict the level of depressive symptoms 12 months into the future
Predict the probability of school dropout in each grade of high school

There are the sorts of tasks the tools are intended to help with.


What do you mean by a “prediction model”?
“Prediction models” predict a dependent variable (\(Y\)) from multiple independent variables (\(X\)s). These are alternately called “prediction algorithms,” “prognostic models,” “forecasting models,” or “screening algorithms.”
When developing these tools, the main use-case we had in mind was that in which the \(X\)s temporally precede the \(Y\) (i.e., predicting from now into the future). However, the tools could also be used for predicting a \(Y\) that is measured concurrently to the \(X\)s.


Why focus on “survey-based” predictors? (NEED TO RE-WORK THIS PARAGRAPH TO “WHY FOCUS ON RISK SCORES”)
Here, the prediction models are “survey-based” because they only use predictors (\(X\)s) that could be measured via a single survey question.
We exclude other measurement modalities (e.g., brain imaging, neuropsychological testing, interviewer impressions) because at present they are too expensive, time-consuming, and/or logistically challenging for widespread implementation.
It is difficult to get professionals and systems to use even basic, survey-based screening algorithms — let alone to collect and integrate multimodal data to feed such an algorithm.
Here, we focus on relatively brief, low-burden, survey-based assessments that are suitable for widespread deployment in applied settings (e.g., schools, clinics, communities).


What are the “tools” you offer here?
The tools included on this website are:

Code to create a tidy dataframe with 2,742 individual survey items to use as predictors (\(X\)s) in prediction models (one click)
Metadata for the 2,742 individual survey items that can be used to guide selection of which to use as predictors (e.g., to identify those measuring similar concepts)

Creating and evaluating a predictive model has a few steps:

Choose what to predict (\(Y\))
Choose the predictors (\(X\)s)
Create an algorithm that takes values on the predictors (\(X\)s) as inputs and gives a score (\(\hat{Y}\)s) as the output
Evaluate the performance of the algorithm created in #3 along a set of predictive performance metrics

When the dataset is fixed, like ABCD, then #2 becomes the most time-consuming step.


I want to create a survey-based prediction model: how do I get started?
First, you’ll need access to the ABCD Study 6.0 data — that is only available [directly from the NIH].
Second, download the code repository [abcd-itembuild]. This code will take the ABCD Study 6.0 data and create a tidy dataframe with individual survey items ready to plug into a predictive model.
Third, reference our preprint to see how to develop a screening measure for prospective prediction of high-risk outcomes from late childhood (ages 9-10) to mid-adolescence (ages 15-16).

title: Tools for Survey-Based Prediction in ABCD
text:
This is a user’s guide to navigating the item metadata (metadata-ABCD-items.csv). The csv file contains several columns meant to help navigate the ABCD dataset while working in R or similar statistical programming languages.



Column
Origin
Contents




domain
ABCD metadata
a sorting system that all ABCD 6.0 release variables were sorted into


sub_domain
ABCD metadata
a subsystem within domain that all ABCD 6.0 release variables were sorted into


source
ABCD metadata
allows us to quickly tell who the respondent/subject was


table_name
ABCD metadata
collections of ABCD variables that were administered and/or collected together


variable
ABCD metadata and Pelham Lab
name of the item; mostly derived from ABCD 6.0 metadata; some created by the Pelham Lab through manipulation


label
ABCD metadata and Pelham Lab
describes the contents of the variable in more detail


has_branching_logic
Pelham Lab
a yes/no indication of the presence of gating


sensitivity
Pelham Lab
an evaluation of how sensitive the content of the variable is


plab_facet
Pelham Lab
a sorting system that all ABCD 6.0 release variables and Pelham Lab variables were sorted into


plab_subfacet
Pelham Lab
a subsystem within domain that all ABCD 6.0 release and Pelham Lab variables were sorted into


alexsa_facet
Pelham Lab
utilizes the subscales from the Assessment of Liability and EXposure to Substance use and Antisocial behavior for Children (ALEXSA) assessment (Ridenour et al., 2009) to sort variables into


nobs_00mo, nobs_12mo, nobs_24mo, nobs_36mo, nobs_48mo, nobs_60mo, or nobs_72mo
Pelham Lab
counts number of observations (nobs) in any given wave of ABCD data collection for a given item





The domain is a sorting system originating from the ABCD metadata that groups all items into the following broad categories:

ABCD (General)
Friends, Family, & Community
Mental Health
Neurocognition
Novel Technologies
Physical Health
Substance Use

There are more domains in ABCD – these are just the ones represented in TSP-ABCD.



The sub_domain is a sorting system originating from the ABCD metadata that groups items into the following categories within domains:

Actigraphy
Administrative
Broad Psychopathology
Cognition
Community
Culture
Demographics
Development
Emotion
Family
Medical
Mood
Nutrition
Parenting
Peers
Physical Health
Psychosis
Psychosocial
Puberty
Questionnaire
School (Demographics)
Screen Use
Sex
Sleep
Social
Stress
SU Attitude
SU Environment
SU Patterns
Task
Temperament/Personality
Work & School

There are more subdomains in ABCD – these are just the ones represented in TSP-ABCD.



Source refers to the informant that item was collected from / administered to. Informants can be:

Youth
Parent
Teacher




The table_name column refers to ABCD tables, or collections of grouped ABCD variables. Datapoints from the same table were administered and collected together. For more information on the ABCD tables, read through the ABCD Release Notes.



The items within the name column are unique variables that can either be found directly in the ABCD dataset or were created by the Pelham Lab through manipulating variables from the ABCD dataset.



The label column tells describes the contents of the item in further detail, typically the way in which the question was actually presented to the respondent. Many items, however, have labels that briefly describe the contents of the item, but not the way in which it was presented to the respondent. For items created by the Pelham Lab, labels will provide a description of the contents of the item.



Utilizes the branching_logic column in the ABCD metadata to produce a binary (yes/no) indication of whether the item has branching logic preceding it.



The sensitivity column captures how jarring the presentation of any given item might be on a survey without context. All items were evaluated by a member of the Pelham Lab as sensitive, maybe sensitive, or not sensitive.



The plab_facet is a sorting system specifically made to sort the items in the ABCD metadata. The plab_facet was created and reviewed by members of the Pelham Lab @ UCSD. The ABCD Release Notes domains were considered in the creation of the plab_facet, but were expanded upon or made more specific in order to classify all items (including items created by the Pelham Lab)



The plab_subfacet is a sorting system within the plab_facet created by members of the Pelham Lab. Categories within the plab_subfacet were only created when clear and necessary categories within a plab_facet category emerged, such that all items in a plab_facet category could fall into a plab_subfacet cateogry of at least three or more items.



The alexsa_facet utilizes the subscales from the Assessment of Liability and EXposure to Substance use and Antisocial behavior for Children (ALEXSA) assessment (Ridenour et al., 2009). The ALEXSA is a child report assessment for predictors of early onset substance abuse and for antisocial behavior.
Items presented in the original ALEXSA assessment fell into one of 34 unique subscales – all of which are domains in the alexsa_facet. At least two lab members were involved in sorting items and reviewing their placement into specific subscales within the alexsa_facet.



The nobs (number of observations) columns represent the counts of any given item at any wave. The waves are represented as months from baseline for clarity.
Here is a what each wave in DEAP currently looks like:
00mo: ses-00A
12mo: ses-01A
24mo: ses-02A
36mo: ses-03A
48mo: ses-04A
60mo: ses-05A
72mo: ses-06A
